keyTakeAways: Los Angeles County District Attorney George Gascón has recommended that a judge resentence Lyle and Erik Menendez, who were convicted in 1996 of murdering their parents, after a 35-year review.

The recommendation comes after defense attorneys presented new evidence, including a sworn statement from Roy Rosselló alleging sexual abuse by Jose Menendez and a letter from Erik Menendez referencing abuse, as part of a 2023 habeas corpus petition.
Under California law, the brothers are now eligible for life with the possibility of parole due to their age at the time of the crime and demonstrated rehabilitation.
Gascón cited changes in societal understanding of abuse, especially sexual abuse, and stated that modern juries would likely view the case differently than in the 1990s.

The decision marks a significant moment in criminal justice reform, especially as it reflects a broader push for reevaluating long-standing convictions in light of new evidence and evolving legal standards.

The case has gained renewed public attention due to the Netflix series 'Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story' and a companion documentary featuring the brothers discussing their abuse and motivations.

Public figures like Kim Kardashian have expressed support, calling the decision a step toward justice and truth, while family members like Jose Menendez’s niece Anamaria Baralt called the move 'brave and necessary'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Los Angeles County District Attorney George Gascón has recommended that a judge resentence Lyle and Erik Menendez, who were convicted in 1996 of murdering their parents Jose and Kitty Menendez in 1989. The decision comes after a 2023 habeas corpus petition presented new evidence, including a sworn statement from Roy Rosselló alleging sexual abuse by Jose Menendez and a letter from Erik Menendez referencing abuse, and following a legal shift in California that allows consideration of abuse and rehabilitation in sentencing. Gascón, who is campaigning on sentencing reform, argues that modern standards of understanding abuse and rehabilitation make the case different from how it was viewed in the 1990s. The brothers, now eligible for life with the possibility of parole due to their age at the time of the crime, are said to have been model prisoners and have contributed positively to prison communities. The decision has drawn public attention, amplified by a Netflix series and documentary, and has been praised by figures like Kim Kardashian and Jose Menendez’s niece Anamaria Baralt, who described it as a 'brave and necessary' step toward justice.
title: Los Angeles District Attorney Recommends Resentencing in Decades-Old Menendez Brothers Murder Case
